column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|salience|identity
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Would you say there has to be a negative consequence to the thing you ca n't stop ?
#Text=No , because think of functional alcoholics , right ?
#Text=Somebody can manage to be a teacher .
#Text=Somebody can manage to be a cop .
#Text=Somebody can manage to be the mayor of Toronto .
#Text=Right .
#Text=And somehow the blowback never hits them .
#Text=Okay .
#Text=Right , but they are still addicted .
#Text=Right .
#Text=Yeah , they 've lost control over use , right ?
#Text=Right .
#Text=Even though they 're managing to sort of stickhandle their way through life .
#Text=Oh , but one of the things I forgot is one of the things is a negative impact on your health as well .
#Text=Well , you can go for a long , long , say , alcoholism .
#Text=You can go a decade or more before you actually suffer significant health consequences from heavy , heavy alcohol use .
#Text=So what I 'd like to find out by the time this episode is over is whether I 'm addicted to sugar or I just really like it .
#Text=Well , yeah , I guess --
#Text=Have you lost control over your consumption of sugar ?
#Text=I guess I have to define --
#Text=Has he ever exhibited any control whatsoever ?
#Text=Yeah , I guess I have to define what that means .
#Text=What control means .
#Text=Sure .
#Text=Yeah .
#Text=Do you keep using despite wanting to stop ?
#Text=Yes .
#Text=Alright .
#Text=Then you may have an addiction to sugar .
#Text=Alright .
#Text=My suspicion is true !
#Text=So I 've got a list of a few specific addictions that we 're probably covering .
#Text=Well , one of them we probably wo n't , because I think we 're going to have an episode specifically on that .
#Text=But drug abuse , of course , is a pattern use of a substance drug in which the user consumes the substance in amounts or with methods which are harmful to themselves or others .
#Text=This adds in the harm aspect of it .

#Text=Sexual addiction is a conceptual model devised in order to provide a scientific explanation for sexual urges , behaviors or thoughts that appear extreme in frequency or feel out of one 's control in terms of being a literal addiction to sexual activity .
#Text=There 's some --
#Text=This is controversial , right ?
#Text=Like this one 's a little controversial ?
#Text=Yeah , it could be just a compulsive thing .
#Text=And again , it 's probably just getting into what do you call addiction .
#Text=Right .
#Text=This is obviously something that you want and it can be causing problems .
#Text=So I think it gets covered here .
#Text=Problem gambling , I think we might have a gambling episode , so I 'm not going to touch too much on this .
#Text=Okay .
#Text=That 's an urge to continuously gamble despite harmful negative consequences or a desire to stop .
#Text=It probably depends on what you 're gambling , like if you put , you know , one of your kids up or something like that .
#Text=That would be a problem .
#Text=That 's a problem .
#Text=Yeah , yeah , it 's not just gambling .
#Text=It 's problem gambling , yeah .
#Text=And then , of course , video game addiction , a relatively new one , is an excessive or compulsive use of computer games or video games which interferes with a person 's everyday life .

#Text=Video game addiction may present as compulsive game playing , social isolation , mood swings , diminished imagination and hyper focus on in - game achievements to the exclusion of other life events .
#Text=What about , like Facebook and other Internet stuff ?
#Text=There is also Internet addiction , yeah .
#Text=In May 2013 , video game addiction was added to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders in the conditions for further study section as Internet gaming disorder .
#Text=This looks interesting .
#Text=So this is -- this is these are those those trial sports for the Olympics that they 're test - driving but are n't mental sports yet .
#Text=Right .
#Text=What ?
#Text=You do n't like sports .
#Text=No , he does n't .
#Text=I understand that .
#Text=This is video game addiction . it 's the -- it 's the ballroom dancing of mental disorders , right .
#Text=Yeah .
#Text=So is there anything on that list that you can get addicted to or anything not on that list that you can get addicted to ?
#Text=A great amount .
#Text=If you start opening up that definition of addiction to other things .
#Text=There 's a show called My Strange Addiction .
#Text=It 's a reality show , and they talk about all sorts of weird things that people are , quote , addicted to .
#Text=Girls are eating chalk and yeah you know .
#Text=Yeah , it 's -- but it 's things like one woman is addicted to licking her cat , right ?
#Text=Right .
#Text=Which feels to me more like a compulsive disorder rather than an addiction .
#Text=Is there a difference , Dr. Rob ?
#Text=Well , these things do shade into one another .
#Text=If you think about addiction as loss of control of use , we can broadly define that in two ways .
#Text=So there could be process addictions , which means addiction to a specific behavior such as Internet addiction , pathological gambling , sex addiction .
#Text=And then there would be the substance use disorders such as substance dependance , where you become -- you 've lost control over use of a particular substance .
#Text=Now , obsessive compulsive disorder is repetitive behaviors that you feel compelled to perform , even though you know they 're irrational .
#Text=Like licking a cat .
#Text=Sure , like licking a cat or like washing your hands .
#Text=Right .
#Text=So a compulsive hand - washer who 's phobic of germs .
#Text=Cause cats ca n't lick themselves .
#Text=Cats most certainly can lick themselves .
#Text=So then the question is , is this person addicted to hand washing ?
#Text=Have they lost control of use over hand washing in the way that an alcoholic has lost control over consumption of alcohol ?
#Text=And I mean , there are similarities in terms of the surface behavior , but in terms of the psychology and the neurobiology , there seem to be pretty specific differences .

#Text=So , for instance , in obsessive compulsive disorder , one of the treatments that 's quite effective would be high dose SSRIs or serotonin reuptake inhibitors , whereas those have no effect at all in classical addiction .
#Text=Okay .
#Text=Such as , say , alcoholism , sex addiction and so forth .
#Text=Right , so we are gon na --
#Text=So we 're talking about medical quantification .
#Text=Yeah , yeah , and you know , neuroimaging looks different in people with OCD versus people with addiction .
#Text=So they shade together , but there do seem to be differences .
